comments.text:
I wonder if people know they released the extended edition for these movies 
which tacks on atleast 45 minutes to each movie.  But Peter Jackson said in 
an interview years ago now that he still has a lot more footage they never 
put in.  He said one day, maybe many years from now that he might release 
an extended extended edition.  Apparently one of the scenes that was not 
put in showed Legolas shooting the Oliphaunt in the head that was pretty 
graphic.  Or at least for a PG13 movie.  So they decided to axe it even for 
the extended edition. ﻿

comments.author: drover

comments.text:
I remember discussing Lord of the Rings with a co worker back in 1999-2000 
when I first saw an article in Time magazine stating  it was being made 
into a film series.  She had never heard of the story as most folks had not 
at that time.

I  had read the books some 18 years prior to the conversation.  I remember 
telling her at the time that IF THEY MADE IT RIGHT, this trilogy would be 
among the greatest films ever made. She kind of looked at me and once she 
realized I wasn't kidding seemed a lot more interested than before.

Peter Jackson made it right.  And his masterpiece made me a prophet.﻿

comments.author: miran02

comments.text:
I was 13 years old when my uncle told me they were filming LOTR, so he gave 
me the books and I read them, then I got hooked..
Then, a few months later the premiere was in school week at night and my 
mum was awesome because she let us go to the premiere at 00:00 to watch the 
movie. It was phenomenal! I got back home around 4:30 and still got to go 
to school but It was worth it. After that It became a family tradition to 
go that late at night.
I will never forget being thrilled watching the helm's deep battle in 
theaters with all the fans clapping and laughing together, it was an epic 
experience, now is really hard to go to cinemas and experience the same 
thing with everyone. I will never forget the incredible experience of 
watching LOTR, I'm glad I was mature enough to go to the cinemas and 
appreciate this movies. I will always be grateful to Tolkien and Peter 
Jackson.
I know the hobbit aren't as great as the LOTR, but the excitement of the 
fans in the theaters is whats makes me go each year, and this movies still 
give me a little taste of LOTR, so I will always welcome that ^^.
Now I hope Peter picks The Silmarillion, some of its chapters will become 
awesome movies!!﻿

comments.author: Emile

comments.text: +Emile agree but i still love the movies
comments.author: OctavianTheGreat

comments.text:
+Emile Watch the production diary of the Hobbit, its not all cgi and I am 
not sure if it is overused, I think the entire lighting and the 48fps makes 
it look like everything was CGI. Dale was built, the shire had less cgi in 
the hobbit than it had in LotR - actually the cgi used in the Hobbit has 
better quality and they are definetly not lazy choosing cgi creates much 
more work. Just compare the facial expressions of the orcs , goblins and 
trolls to lord of the rings. No doubt LotR is an amazing trilogy but the 
Hobbit is not that much worse I'd say, we dont need argue that they are not 
on the same level but none the less I think the Hobbit is the best Trilogy 
released as of late.
comments.author: Crowh

comments.text:
I TOTALLY, 100% agree with u. They did so much fantastic, epic work with 
Lotr, all those clay models and miniatures. The hobbit was sloppy by 
comparison
comments.author: R Kaiser

comments.text:
+132shredder The Hobbit was moderately enjoyable but cringe worthy at most 
times, the LOTR is a modern cinematic masterpiece. Even its imperfections 
are perfect. It paid great attention to detail and it redefined Hollywood. 
The Hobbit as one movie would have worked great but Peter Jackson got the 
Dragon Fever. (If you know what I mean wink) I hope he retires or goes back 
to making awesome comedy/horror films.
comments.author: Kas De Costa

comments.text: +SlavjanA Yeah, but digital usually starts off more saturated any way.
comments.author: 132shredder

comments.text:
+132shredder You do realise that the red epic cameras actually unsaturated, 
so they had to over saturate the colours on the sets, etc. They also over 
saturated them because the hobbit is a trilogy for kids, so they wanted to 
make it lighter/brighter/more vibrant. Finally, the hobbit had more cgi.

comments.author: 132shredder

comments.text:
It's not just the CGI. The Hobbit trilogy was basically an uninspired, 
bloated parody of LOTR.
comments.author: Kas De Costa

comments.text:
CGI in The Hobbit was only used as much as in The Lord of the Rings, but 
The Hobbit was filmed with a digital camera not with film. Film looks more 
realistic and colours don't pop as much (I don't think you can change it). 
Like there were only 2 CGI orcs in The Hobbit (Bolg and Azog) while the 
others were real people. I've seen others complain about real people in 
makeup being CGI (I have the behind the scenes). Now I know the trolls were 
CGI, but so were the Oliphaunts in Lord of the Rings. We can look at the 
CGI used in both.
Lord of the Rings
1. Balrog
2.Cave trolls
3. Fireworks
4. Gollum
5. Mumakil 
6. Fell beasts
7. Eagles
8.Green screens
9. Eye of Sauron
10. Shelob

The Hobbit
1. Two orcs
2. Trolls
3.Dragon
4.Eagles
5. Beorn in his bear form
6.Green screens
7. Gollum
8. Sauron
9. Spawn of Shelob
And this is where my mind went blank. But yes, my point is The Hobbit 
pretty much had just as much CGI and yet looks worse due to being recorded 
not with film but digital.
comments.author: 132shredder

comments.text:
the animation in lotr looks like shit. but what they did is they used 
little of it. they have many men who played for the armies and build sets, 
that is why it looks so much better than all that CGI of the hobbit.
comments.author: NoDimeToMyName

comments.text:
Agreed, practical is always > cgi. They should have just stuck with makeup 
and props. I do know that they did make the animation more 
"lighter/brighter/vibrant/smoother?" (I'm not quite sure how to put it, but 
like they made it more "cartoon-y" if that makes sense). That's why Gollum 
doesn't look as realistic in the hobbit as he did in lotr, and why the 
molten gold looks so fake/animated, it was all on purpose in order to stick 
with the target audience of the book, it being towards children. To me the 
hobbit does an amazing job in starting off the epic climb, from the first 
hobbit film to the last lotr film it's a great ride.
comments.author: SlavjanA

comments.text:
+Cryer24597 I totally agree. WETA had done an amazing job with all the 
props in LOTR.
comments.author: Emile

comments.text:
+DigitalBlawks I couldn't disagree more. No CGI orc in The Hobbit looks 
even half as good as the average make-upcostume orc from LOTR.
comments.author: Cryer24597

comments.text:
Meh I like what eh did with the Orks. I like how he chose the CG faces, 
they allowed for more creativity, beyond the limits of the masked orks from 
LOTR.
comments.author: Emk Mage

comments.text:
+Monkey Man I call it the Lucas Syndrome.  Over-reliance on CG bombast, and 
less emphasis on characters, story and structure.  Hence when the CG 
effects get boring and routine, you more easily notice the lack of the 
latter.  Just like the original Star Wars Trilogy had practical  effects 
that SUPPORTED the story and the prequel trilogy did not.  Same goes for PJ 
and LOTR.  The ending of DOS made me so furious.  It was akin to ending The 
Two Towers just as the Urak-Hai begin the charge on Helm's Deep, and 
Theodin's line, "so it begins."  Bad filmmaking should not be rewarded by 
seeing the "next chapter."
comments.author: CaptWithNoName

comments.text:
Strange, each of the hobbit films had a budget of 200 million or more and 
had the newer technology and yet somehow... the practical effects of the 
Lord of the rings trilogy looked much better overall. Can somebody please 
enlighten me how the hobbit franchise being the one with the newer 
technology and bigger budget look worse than the previous franchise over 10 
years ago with a much smaller budget.

Just combine any two (Or even one) of the LOTR films STILL being under 200 
million and it will STILL be superior in almost everything than what the 
Hobbit has to offer.
 Was P.J afraid that not many people will come to watch the film so he 
decided to spend the majority of the budget on advertisements? Even though 
there are millions of tolkien and lotr fanboys that would watch the film 
anyway? Even though the lotr is considered to be one of the few franchises 
that reached the pinnacle of the most successful money making at the box 
office of all time?
comments.author: Monkey Man

yea compare the orcs from lord of the rings to the   hobbit ones are so

comments.author: The Real Ryan Conway

comments.text:
+silver raven You're right, even lotrs wasn't 100% book accurate, parts 
were removed, moved from one book to another, and changed, yet lotr is the 
best trilogy of films ever made. I even get why people complain about the 
CGI but the fact of the matter is the hobbit is for children. The lightened 
cgi/animation, and amount of it, was done on purpose to cater to the target 
audience, so whilst adults might find it displeasing, children wont be 
scared by it and enjoy it. Imo the hobbit and lotr are both fantastic 
trilogies, and the hobbit at least does lotr justice by adding extra steps 
to the hierarchical progression of the films (from the first hobbit film, 
to the last lotr film, just gets better and better), adding to the epic 
experience.

to the book? There won't be any surprises!
